title.narrative: Improved access to WASH for disadvantaged communities in Zimbabwe-MF4

description.narrative:
Part of the Match Fund 4 project (including projects in DRC and Uganda) this project aims to increase sustainable access to improved WASH facilities in rural disadvantaged communities in Zimbabwe. We will directly provide WASH services alongside investing in social mobilisation of communities to influence local government on policy implementation, and strengthen water user groups to adopt correct use and maintenance of water points. The beneficiary communities were selected due to their high levels of vulnerability to droughts and inadequate access to WASH services and facilities. These target groups also experience interrupted access to clean drinking water due to non-functional hand pumps. Specific groups to be reached within the selected underserved communities include women and men in underserved villages including female headed households, the elderly, people with disabilities, and people living with HIV/AIDS. The targeted districts Binga and Gokwe are among the poorest and most marginalised areas of Zimbabwe, prone to food insecurity and with very poor infrastructure and service provision. These areas are geographically remote with very poor soils and arid landscapes, characterised by livestock rearing as the main livelihoods option, with a consequently widely-spaced population; hence difficult to access for service provision. As a consequence of limited access to adequate WASH services, communities in these districts are very vulnerable to diarrhoea. The livelihoods of the local population are also heavily affected by the water access restrictions. Livestock rearing, the main livelihoods activity, is hindered by the difficulty in reaching reliable sources of drinking water.
A weak economy and poor institutional capacity are leading to inadequate water sector investment, inappropriate use of water supply technologies and are contributing to depleting the communities’ skill base. The situation is exacerbated by the absence of a holistic and coordinated approach to water and land management in the target districts. Water resources are currently managed by different government ministries, resulting in a lack of sector coordination.
